decision.reasoning: I've known Paulie thirty-plus years, and the man wears his guilt like a cheap suit when he lies—his eyes flick, his hands twitch, and he can't let a silence sit without filling it with bullshit. Out here on this boat, no crew, no wire, just the two of us and the ocean—this is the perfect living room to squeeze the truth out of him instead of taking him straight to swim class and maybe losing a loyal made guy. I’ll bring up the Ginny joke, watch how he reacts, throw in that I heard it came from New York circles, let him scramble. If he cracks, I get confirmation and a choice on what happens next. If he doesn’t, maybe I read the signs wrong and I keep my ear open another day. Either way, I ain’t pulling the trigger till I’m sure, because once he goes over the side, there’s no rewind button.

This ain't no easy call. Paulie's a earner, a good soldier for thirty years. But leaks? That's a cancer. You don't whack a guy on suspicion, not a made man anyway. But I gotta send a message, make it clear I know somethin's up. Alone on this boat, he's listenin' to every word. I'm gonna lean on him, remind him of his loyalty, and let him know I got eyes everywhere. If he's smart, he'll clean up his act. If he ain't, then we can talk about a 'set up' later. I ain't burnin' this bridge unless I got a shovel and a match in my hands.

I need to get Paulie to confess or show his loyalty. We're out here alone and if he's been talking to Johnny, now's the time to know. Let him know I'm aware of the leak and if he doesn't come clean, something real bad is gonna happen. But if he shows me he's still a true soldier, I'll give him a pass. Need to keep things in house and avoid a full sitdown which could spook the rest of the crew.

Paulie's been with the family for decades, so I need to be sure before taking drastic action. Out here on the water, I've got him isolated and can apply pressure directly. Threatening him with the consequences of betraying the family—while watching his reaction closely—will either make him confess if he's guilty or show genuine confusion if he's loyal. This way, I can gauge the truth without immediately ordering a hit that might cost me a longtime soldier.

Paulie's been with us 30 years—he's earned the right to a conversation before anything permanent. Out here, he's got nowhere to run. I'll look him in the eye, remind him of the loyalty this family demands, and lay out the consequences if he's been talking to Johnny Sack. If he confesses or slips, then I handle it. If he holds firm and I believe him, we go back—but I watch him closer than ever.

Paulie's been with the family for 30 years—he deserves a chance to explain himself face-to-face before any extreme measures. A sitdown on the boat forces him to confront the allegations directly, and his reaction will tell me everything I need to know. If he's guilty, the isolation means there's no witnesses; if he's clean, I avoid killing a loyal soldier unnecessarily.

Paulie's been with the family for 30 years, so I don't wanna whack him if he's innocent, but these leaks are killing us. Bein' out here on the boat alone, it's the perfect spot to put the fear of God into him, make him talk, and see if he slips up. If he's guilty, he'll crack; if not, I haven't lost a good earner yet.

Here's the thing - Paulie's been with me thirty fucking years. When it comes down to it, blood or no blood, I need to know where his loyalties lie. I'm not about to whack a made guy, a thirty-year earner, on a fucking hunch. That's bad business. But I also can't have him running back to Johnny Sack every time we have a sit-down.

So I get in his face. I let him know I know about the leaks, about the fucking joke reaching Johnny's ears. I remind him that snitches get stitches, or in our line of work, they get concrete shoes. I don't gotta spell it out for him - he's been around long enough to know what happens to people who talk out of school to New York.

But here's the key - I give him an out. I tell him if he comes clean right now, we work this out family style. Maybe he's feeding Johnny bullshit to protect us, maybe he's playing both sides. I'll know by his reaction. If he gets defensive, starts sweating, can't look me in the eye - then I know. If he challenges me, gets in my face right back, maybe he's clean.

This way, I don't lose a loyal soldier if I'm wrong. And if I'm right, I put the fear of God into him so he either stops the leaks or makes a mistake that gives me the proof I need. Either way, I come out ahead without having to do something permanent that I might regret.

I need to handle this delicate situation carefully. Paulie's been with us for thirty years - that means something. But the leak about Ralph's joke is serious business that could start a war with New York. I can't just whack him based on suspicion alone, but I can't ignore it either. Out here on the water, away from everyone else, I'll confront him directly - make it clear I know information is leaking and watch his reaction. If he's guilty, the fear in his eyes will tell me everything I need to know. If he's innocent, his genuine confusion and anger at being accused will be obvious. This way I get the truth without making an irreversible mistake. Paulie's old school - if I show him I'm serious about this leak, he'll either confess or help me find who's really talking.

I’m not 100% sure he’s the rat, but I can’t take the chance of leaks to Johnny Sack. Out here in the middle of the ocean, I’ll put the fear of Davy Jones in him. If he’s innocent, he’ll back off and swear loyalty. If he’s guilty, he’ll crack or I’ll know what to do next.

Killing Paulie without absolute proof could destabilize the family and erode trust among other members, as he's been loyal for decades. A sitdown back on land will give me the opportunity to confront him directly, gauge his reaction, and investigate further before making a final decision. It's a measured approach that preserves family unity and addresses the issue strategically.

Paulie's got seniority and history with the family, but if he's been leaking, that's a line you can't just let slide. At the same time, a direct hit, especially if you're wrong, could cause blowback from the old guard and hurt morale—plus, you don't have concrete proof. Best play is to set Paulie up with false information, something juicy that only he hears, and see if it gets back to Johnny Sack. This way, you confirm your suspicion without risking taking out a loyal man on just a hunch. If the info leaks, you got your answer; if not, you give Paulie the benefit of the doubt and keep the family solid.

Paulie's got motive—beef over money—and history with Johnny Sack. That joke only came from inside, and he's the one it points to. Thirty years don't mean shit if he's burnin' us. Leaks like this get people dead. Boat's the spot, no witnesses, no mess. Can't take chances, gotta end it now.

I'm not gonna clip Paulie on a hunch. Thirty years this man's been with me, with my father's people before that. Yeah, he's been bitching about money, and yeah, he's got history with Johnny Sack. But I'm sitting here looking at him, and I don't got proof. I got suspicion. I got circumstantial bullshit. You know what I do got? A guy who's killed for this family, bled for this family, done time and kept his mouth shut. I whack him out here, dump him in the ocean, and what if I'm wrong? Then I murdered a loyal soldier because I got paranoid. That's not justice, that's... that's Stalin. I'll watch him closer. I'll feed him some bad information, see if it gets back to New York. Set up a test. But I'm not pulling that trigger today, not without knowing for sure. I gotta live with myself. I gotta sleep at night. We head back to shore, I keep my eyes open, and I find out the truth the right way.

Paulie’s been a loyal earner for decades; if I whack him without proof I risk tearing the crew apart and looking paranoid. Out here alone I can scare the shit outta him, press him hard about the leak, watch every twitch. If he cracks, I finish it right then; if he holds, I keep him close and feed him marked info to see if it reaches Johnny Sack. Fear keeps him in line and buys me the certainty I need before taking irreversible steps.

I need to cut through the bullshit here. Paulie's been with me since the beginning, but thirty years don't mean shit when someone's feeding information to Johnny Sack. This leak puts us all at risk, especially after Ralph's joke about Ginny. I know Paulie was mad about the money, and he's got history with Johnny from back in the day. Out here on this goddamn boat, it's just me and him. No eyes, no ears. Time to take off the gloves. I'll stare him right in those crazy eyes of his and make it clear what happens if he's the one talking. If he's loyal, he'll understand and shut his mouth. If he's guilty... well, the ocean's deep enough. But I've got to be careful—killing the wrong guy would turn the crew against me. This needs to be a gut check, not a bloodbath.

I ain't whacking Paulie based on suspicion - thirty years of service earns him more than that. But we're alone out here, no wires, no distractions. This is the moment for truth. I look him dead in the eye and let him know I know something's been going on. I tell him about the leak, about Johnny Sack knowing things only our inner circle knew. I watch his face, his hands, every fucking twitch. I make it clear - crystal clear - that if he's been talking to New York, now's his chance to come clean and we handle it in-house. But if I find out later he lied to my face out here, there's no coming back from that. Paulie's old school, he understands omerta. If he's guilty and confesses, maybe we work something out - cut off contact, restitution, proving loyalty again. If he's innocent, he'll be pissed but he'll understand why I had to ask. And if he's guilty and lies? His reaction will tell me what I need to know, and I'll deal with it then. But I don't clip a thirty-year guy on a hunch. Not yet.

We’re on the water for a reason. I’m not putting a bullet in a 30-year man on a hunch, but I’m not walking away blind either. I press him—hard—about the joke, about Johnny, about the timing with his beef over money. I watch his eyes, his tells, I needle him with details only the rat would know, and I make him talk. I float a false detail mid-convo—something only he’ll think is valuable—to see if it shows up in New York later. I also angle for a confession with the carrot and the stick: I tell him I can fix his money grievance if he comes clean, and I let him see I’m willing to do what needs doing right here if he doesn’t. If he stays solid and I don’t get the break, I don’t splash him today; I take him back, put a quiet tail on him, shake his phones, and plant that canary seed. If the fake intel surfaces with Johnny, I got my answer and then he goes. If it doesn’t, then maybe it’s not Paulie and I avoid killing a loyal soldier on bad intel. Either way, I control the flow from here on out and tighten the circle until I know for sure.

I can't whack a guy who's been with me for 30 years without being certain. But I need to know the truth. Out here on the boat, just the two of us, I'll put some fear into him - let him know I know about the leaks, see how he reacts. If he's guilty, he'll crack under pressure. If he's innocent, he'll be genuinely confused and angry. Either way, I get my answer without doing something irreversible. And if he is the rat, well... we're already out here on the water.

Paulie's been with me for 30 years, but this leak stinks of him ratting to Johnny Sack. We're alone out here on the boat—perfect spot to get the truth. I'll lean on him hard, threaten to make him fish food if he's been talking. See if he cracks or proves his loyalty. If he's clean, I don't whack a good soldier; if not, I handle it right here.

I can't just whack Paulie without being sure. He's been with the family for over 30 years. But I also can't let these leaks continue to Johnny Sack. I need to confront him directly, see how he reacts. If he's guilty, he'll probably show it in his face or his words. If he's innocent, he'll be offended and maybe even pissed off at me for suspecting him. Either way, I'll get more information than I have now before making a final decision. Out here on the water, there's nowhere for him to run if things go south.

I don’t whack Paulie on a hunch. Thirty years in, you don’t throw that away without proof, and I’m not starting a civil war in my own head out on the water. But I also can’t let leaks keep happening. So I keep it calm on the boat, feel him out, let him talk, see if he hangs himself—then I get back to shore and I move it the right way: quiet sit-down with my people, tighten who hears what, and I set a trap. I feed a canary story—something only Paulie would hear—and watch where it lands. If it gets to Johnny again, now I got certainty and I handle it. If it doesn’t, Paulie stays a soldier and I still close the pipe.

I got him out here on the boat, miles from shore. He knows what this could be. But Paulie's been with me 30 years. You don't clip a guy like that on a hunch. There's no concrete proof. So, I put the fear of God into him. I talk around it, I bring up Johnny, I bring up loyalty. I let him stew in it. I let him think I'm gonna do it. Then, I let him go. If he's innocent, he's scared straight and knows I'm not to be fucked with. If he's guilty, he's so terrified he'll never open his mouth to Johnny Sack again. Either way, I win, and I don't whack a made guy unless I'm 100%.

I look at him sitting there, terrified. I got the urge to toss him over, sure. He's a pain in my ass and he talks too much. But looking in his eyes... I don't see a rat like Pussy. I see a lonely old man who wants to feel important. If I whack him on a hunch, I destroy the last link to my father and the old days. I'll let him sweat it out on the ride back—let him think his number is up. That fear will keep his mouth shut better than a bullet would. I ain't killing a captain over a fat joke without absolute proof.

Out here on the boat, I stare at him and I see two things at the same time: the kid who carried my old man’s bags and took collars for this family, and the old man who’s been bitchin’ about envelopes and playin’ both sides of the street with Johnny Sack. I already went through this once with Pussy—I pulled that trigger because I had hard proof. A wire. With Paulie, I got motive and opportunity, but no certainty. Thirty years is a long time. I whack him on a maybe, I’m not just killin’ a soldier, I’m sendin’ a message that history don’t mean shit, and that’ll put fear and resentment into every guy who’s been with me since the beginning. That kind of paranoia destroys a boss. But if he’s the leak and I do nothin’, New York keeps knowin’ what I said in my own back room. So right here, I don’t pull the trigger. I turn the screws. I let him know I heard about the joke gettin’ to Johnny, I make him sweat, I remind him what happened to Pussy. I keep the threat just under the surface so he walks off this boat feelin’ like he just dodged a bullet, literally. Then back on land, I isolate him: cut down his access to sensitive talk, keep him busy on earners where anything he repeats don’t hurt me. Meanwhile, I run a canary trap: I feed him a specific piece of bullshit—something small but juicy that only he hears—and I wait to see if it comes back to me from New York. Maybe I even route it through someone I know talks to him so it looks natural. If that info shows up on the other side of the river, then I know, 100%, and the next ‘fishing trip’ ain’t gonna end with us both comin’ home. If it doesn’t, maybe he was just runnin’ his mouth once, or somebody else is the rat. So on this boat, I keep the gun in my waistband, talk to him, scare him, then bring him back. I use him as bait instead of chum. That way I protect the family without gambling a three-decade loyalty on a hunch.

Paulie has been with this family since my father wore short pants. I suspect he's the one leaking to Johnny Sack, but I don't have the proof I need to whack a guy with thirty years of service. If I'm wrong, I lose a loyal soldier and look like a paranoid prick to the rest of the crew. I'll watch him like a hawk, but for now, we just fish.

Paulie's been with this family since my old man was running the streets. You don't clip a guy with thirty years of service over a 'maybe'—it'd start a mutiny with the rest of the guys. I put the fear of God in him out there on the water, and if the leak was him, he'll think twice before opening his mouth to Johnny Sack again. For now, his history buys him a pass.

Paulie's been with us for decades, but if he's the leak to Sack, letting him live means more hits on our business. Can't take that chance—business is business. We're out here alone, no witnesses, perfect spot to clip him and dump the body. If I'm wrong, it's a loss for the family, but better that than bleeding secrets to New York.

I don’t whack Paulie on a hunch. Thirty years in, that’s a move you don’t get to take back, and if I’m wrong I just proved to everybody that loyalty means nothin’ when the boss gets a mood. On the other hand, if he’s been runnin’ his mouth to John, I can’t let it keep goin’ either.

So on this boat, I lean on him—quiet, personal, make it clear I know the joke got to New York and it could only be somebody close. I watch his eyes, his breathing, if he starts over-explainin’ or gettin’ indignant. I don’t accuse him flat-out with nothin’ in my hand; I let him hang himself if he’s gonna.

Then I set him up: I compartmentalize what he hears from me, and I feed him a piece of “inside” information that’s harmless but unique—something only he would know. If that exact thing shows up with Johnny, now I got proof, not feelings. At the same time I have Sil keep an eye, phone, meetings, who he’s talkin’ to—no drama, just quiet surveillance.

If the canary sings, then it’s handled permanently. If it don’t, I keep him close and I still tighten the flow of sensitive business. Either way, I stop the leak without killin’ a maybe-innocent guy in the middle of the ocean.

I'm gonna feel him out, see how he reacts. Maybe he cracks, gives me somethin'. I don't wanna make a move without bein' sure. Threatenin' him gets him to talk, and I can gauge his reaction. If he's guilty, he might get desperate or angry, and that's when I know I've got the right guy.

I need to know if Paulie is the leak. Threatening him might get him to crack and reveal the truth. If he's loyal, he'll deny it and I'll know I was wrong. If he's not loyal, I'll take care of the problem.

I’m not killing a loyal man on a hunch. The smart move is to pull Paulie into a formal sit-down—with a trusted witness or the consigliere present—so we can press him for the source of the leak, look at the facts, and set the record straight. This protects the family’s discipline and keeps leverage in the right hands. If the leak comes from him, deal with it through the proper channels; if not, we avert an internal bloodbath and preserve loyalty. Impulsive violence here risks losing a soldier for nothing.

I don't whack a made guy on a gut feeling — Paulie's been with this family thirty years. Out here, miles from shore, I put him under the light: I make him feel the consequences, stare him down, remind him what loyalty costs and who pays for betrayal. I give him one chance to explain himself, watch his reactions, squeeze him for the truth. If he cracks and confesses, we handle it properly; if he lies or stonewalls, I make it clear he's gonna be brought to a formal sitdown and that his life ain't a sure thing anymore. No rash moves until I get an answer — but I make sure he knows the price of screwing around.

I need a face-to-face with Little Carmine and the other New York bosses. Phil wants blood, but he doesn't get to dictate terms to me. I'll propose we handle Tony B ourselves—in a way that satisfies New York's need for retribution without starting a war. Maybe we make Tony B disappear quietly, or we find a creative solution that lets Phil save face. But handing him over for torture? That sets a precedent I can't allow. Better to negotiate from strength than start a war we might not win.

Paulie's past loyalty and the isolated setting make threatening a way to probe his reaction; if he's leaking, his response will betray him, and if not, it serves as a warning to deter future leaks without irreversible consequences for an innocent soldier.

Out here on the water, I got the perfect setup to do him like Pussy. And yeah, it crosses my mind. But Pussy we had dead to rights with the feds on those tapes. With Paulie, all I got is circumstantial shit: he’s been cranky about money, he’s got history with Johnny, and the joke traveled in a way that fits him. That’s strong, but it ain’t proof. Whacking a 30‑year man, a capo, on just a feeling? That’s not just murder, that’s destabilizing the whole fuckin’ family. Guys start wondering who’s next every time there’s a whisper. I can’t look weak with New York, but I also can’t look like a paranoid lunatic with my own people. So on this boat, I lean into the fear. I let him see in my eyes how close he is to going overboard. I press him on the leak, on Johnny, on his resentments. I watch his reactions, his tells – I know this guy for decades, I’ll know if he’s lying or if he’s genuinely hurt I even suspect him. I make it absolutely clear: any talking to New York, any more bullshit, and he disappears, no discussion. Then when we get back, I keep him close, not far. I quietly strip some power, isolate him, and I feed him very specific, traceable information only he hears. If that same info shows up in New York, then I know for sure, and next time there’s no fishing trip, no warning – it’s a straight-up hit. But today, on just suspicion, I stop short of killing a guy who’s been earning for me and my old man for three decades. I use fear, not a body, to send the message.

1. **Loyalty Test**: Paulie’s been with the family for 30 years—longer than most. That kind of history ain’t something you just throw away on a hunch. But loyalty ain’t just about time served; it’s about respect and trust. If he’s been running his mouth to Johnny Sack, that’s a betrayal of the worst kind. I gotta make sure he understands the gravity of what he’s done—if he’s done it.

    2. **Controlled Environment**: We’re out here in the middle of the ocean, just the two of us. No witnesses, no interruptions. This is the perfect place to apply some pressure, see how he reacts. If he’s guilty, he’ll sweat. If he’s innocent, he’ll be pissed but he’ll understand why I had to ask.

    3. **The Joke Leak**: That joke about Johnny’s wife? It’s a small thing, but it’s personal. If Paulie leaked it, it means he’s got a big mouth *and* he’s got no loyalty to the family’s code. That’s a double whammy. I gotta make it clear that talking to New York—especially about family business—is a death sentence. No exceptions.

    4. **Paulie’s Temper**: Paulie’s got a short fuse, and he’s always been a little unpredictable. If I accuse him outright and he’s innocent, he might flip out, and then I’ve got a mess on my hands. But if I threaten him just enough to make him squirm, I can read him. If he’s guilty, he’ll either crack or get defensive in a way that gives him away. If he’s innocent, he’ll be mad, but he’ll know I had to be sure.

    5. **The Fishing Trip Setup**: I didn’t bring him out here for no reason. The isolation, the water—it’s all part of the message. I gotta make him feel the weight of the situation. Maybe I don’t pull the trigger today, but I gotta make sure he knows that if he’s been talking, his time is limited. And if he hasn’t, he better watch his back because someone in the family is a rat.

    6. **Long-Term Play**: Even if Paulie ain’t the rat, this sends a message to the whole family. Word gets around that I’m not messing around with leaks. It keeps everyone on their toes. And if Paulie *is* the rat, this is his last warning. Next time, it won’t be a conversation—it’ll be a swim with the fishes.

    **How I’ll Play It**:
    - Start casual, like we’re just two guys out on the water. Let him relax, think this is just a fishing trip.
    - Then, drop the hammer. Mention the joke, watch his reaction. If he gets defensive or starts sweating, I know I’m onto something.
    - Lay it out for him: ‘Paulie, I gotta know—you been talking to Johnny Sack? Because if you have, that’s a problem. A *big* problem.’
    - Let the silence hang. The ocean’s got a way of making a man feel small, alone. That’s when the truth comes out.
    - If he denies it, I’ll give him a chance to prove his loyalty. Maybe send him on a job that’ll test his allegiance. If he passes, great. If he fails, well… the ocean’s deep out here.
    - If he admits it—or if I’m convinced he’s lying—I’ll make sure he understands this is his last chance. No more warnings. And if he’s smart, he’ll take the out I give him and disappear. If he’s not, he’ll end up feeding the fish.

decision.reasoning: I need to set a meeting with Phil to talk through this. I grew up with Tony B, but I can't have a war with New York. I can arrange a meeting where Phil and I handle it ourselves, so Tony B won't be tortured and we avoid the bigger conflict.

Listen to me, you know how this works. I don't like this situation any more than you do, but I gotta buy some time here. I need a sitdown with the New York brass - Butchie, Albie, maybe Johnny Sac if he's still in the loop. This thing with Tony B, it's a fucking mess, but I can't just hand over my own blood. That's principle, that's family. But I ain't stupid either - I know we can't afford a war with New York over this. They're bigger, got more soldiers, more sway. I need to negotiate, maybe offer them something else - territory, a bigger cut, something that makes them whole without giving them my cousin to torture. Tony B fucked up royal, going off the reservation like that, but I'm still the boss of this family and I decide who gets hit and how. Phil wants personal satisfaction? I get it. But this is business, and in business sometimes you don't get what you want. I gotta try to make this right without starting a bloodbath that'll bury us all.

Tony B acted without my blessing and killed a made guy. Handing him over to Phil would show weakness, but protecting him means war with New York. The only honorable move in our world is to handle it myself—order the hit on Tony B to settle the debt and avoid all-out war, while showing I maintain control.

Tony B is my cousin, but he made a move without my sanction and put the entire family at risk. Handing him over to Phil would be a sign of weakness and disrespect to the family. Doing it myself is too personal; we grew up together. Ordering a hit is the cleanest way—it shows New York we handle our own problems, maintains our dignity, and avoids an all-out war. It's business, not personal.

I brought him out here to do it. I'm sitting here looking at him, this guy I've known my whole life, and I got my hand near the gun. But I keep thinking - what if I'm wrong? Paulie's a pain in the ass, he's cheap, he complains, but thirty years. Thirty years he's been with this family. Big Pussy, I had the proof. I heard him on tape with my own ears. With Paulie, I got what - he knows Johnny Sack from the old days? He was pissed about some money? That's not enough. I clip him out here, I gotta live with that. And if he wasn't the leak, the real rat is still out there laughing at me. No. I let him talk. I watch him. When we get back, I feed him some information - something specific - and see if it makes its way to New York. Then I'll know for sure. And if it does, there's always another boat trip.

Paulie's been family for 30 years, but the leak about Johnny Sack's wife points directly to him—financial gripes and his past ties to New York make him the prime suspect. I can't whack a soldier without solid proof, but we're alone on this boat with no witnesses. I'll confront him head-on, remind him of the consequences for betrayal, and watch him sweat. If he cracks and confesses, it confirms everything and I handle it right here. If he holds firm, I'll back off for now but put heavy surveillance on him the second we hit land. Either way, this stops the leaks without risking an innocent man's life prematurely.

Out there on the water it’s tempting to make it simple, but I’m not clipping a guy like Paulie on a hunch—thirty years in, if I’m wrong I’m the one who betrayed this thing. So I keep my head, let him feel I’m not thrilled about him and Johnny Sack being so chummy, and I tighten the circle. Then I set a test: I give Paulie a piece of inside bullshit that only a couple people could know, and I watch where it ends up. If it makes its way to New York, now I got proof and we handle it. If it doesn’t, then I stop torturing myself and I keep him in the fold—with a short leash.

This is business, not personal. My cousin fucked up by killing Billy without my permission. Now he's put me in a position where I gotta choose between blood and the family. Phil's got New York behind him, and if I protect Tony B, we go to war. Good guys die. Maybe me. Maybe Paulie, Sil, Christopher. All over something I didn't authorize. If I hand him to Phil, he gets tortured, and I look weak to my own crew. But if I take care of this myself—quick and clean—I show New York I handle my problems, I show my crew I make the hard calls, and I give my cousin a more merciful end than Phil would. It's the only move that keeps peace and shows I'm still in charge.

Look, this ain't no damn picnic. Between New York and my own cousin, I gotta make a choice. Phil ain't gonna stop, and neither is New York. It's either a war that'll wipe us all out, or I handle this myself. No way I'm handing my own blood over to Phil to be tortured, that's just not how we do things. Tony B left me no choice. I gotta do what's best for the family, even if it breaks my heart.

Tony B's my blood, we grew up together, but this hit on Billy Leotardo's got Phil Leotardo and all of New York breathin' down my neck. They want him handed over for torture, or it's war with Jersey. War means bodies, rackets shut down, feds all over us. Can't do that to the family. I handle it myself—clean, quick. Send word to Tony B, tell him it's the only way. Silvio or Chris takes care of it. Saves the peace, saves the business.

Tony B is family, and it kills me to even think about this, but his rogue actions have put the entire family at risk. Going to war with New York would mean bloodshed and the end of everything we've built. I can't hand him over to Phil for torture, but I have to handle this myself to maintain some control and avoid total catastrophe. Ordering this hit protects the crew and sends a message that I'm in charge.

I can't just whack a made guy who's been with the family for 30 years on a hunch, especially Paulie. He's a high earner and a loyal soldier, most of the time. But I can't let him think he can talk to Johnny Sack behind my back. I need to put the fear of God into him right here, make him understand that if I find out he's the leak, he sleeps with the fishes. I'll watch his reaction—if he sweats, I know he's guilty. If he stands his ground, maybe I keep him around a little longer.

This is the hardest decision I gotta make, but I can't let my family go to war with New York over Tony B's stupidity. He killed Billy without my say-so - that's on him. If I hand him over to Phil, he's gonna torture him for days, maybe weeks. I can't let my cousin suffer like that. Better I handle it myself - quick and clean. One bullet, it's over. I'll tell Phil that Tony B is dead, show him the body. New York gets their justice, we avoid a war that could destroy both families, and Tony B doesn't have to endure what Phil would do to him. Sometimes being the boss means making the hard choices that nobody else can make.

Family comes first—the DiMeo family, that is. I can't let this turn into a war with New York; it'll destroy everything we've built. Tony B went rogue, killed Billy without my say-so. Handing him over means Phil tortures him slow—that's no way for my cousin to go. Better I handle it quick and clean, on my terms. It's a tough call, but blood or not, you don't jeopardize the whole operation.

Out here on the boat, it’d be real easy to do another Pussy Bonpensiero, toss him over and let the ocean keep its mouth shut. But with Pussy, I had the wire, I had confirmations. With Paulie, all I got is circumstantial bullshit: he’s tight with Johnny, he’s been whining about money, and the joke got over there. That’s not enough to bury a guy who’s been breaking heads for this family since my old man’s day. I whack Paulie on a hunch and I send a message to everybody that thirty years of service don’t mean shit, that you can get clipped over gossip and vibes. That makes the whole crew paranoid, and paranoid earners don’t earn. On this boat I play it friendly, break his balls a little, let him see I’m not blind, watch how he reacts. Then back on land, I set the canary trap: I feed Paulie one piece of sensitive info nobody else hears, something that would definitely get back to Johnny if it’s still leaking. I got him watched, I got my ears in New York. If that story shows up over there, then I know it’s him and next time we go on a boat, he ain’t coming back. If it doesn’t, maybe he just ran his mouth once and the scare straightens him out. So I don’t pull the trigger today; I set him up to prove it one way or the other before I make a move I can’t take back.

I can't hand him over to Phil. That shah of Iran will torture him, turn him into a piece of meat. I can't have that on my conscience, he's family. But I can't go to the mattresses against New York over this neither; we don't have the manpower and my captains are gettin' restless. Tony B went off the reservation and he put me in a box. I gotta go up to the farm and handle this myself. Quick and painless. It's the only way to stop the war and save him from Phil's basement.

I gotta think about this like the boss. Billy Leotardo was a made guy in New York, so this is blood in the streets now. If I just hand Tony B over to Phil, I look weak as hell in front of my crew. They’ll question if I’d throw any of *my* guys under the bus when the heat gets hot. But if I say no to handing him over, Phil’s howling for war with New York. That’s bad business for everyone—hits on crews, cops sniffing around more than usual, maybe even getting some feds stirred up again. I can’t have open war breaking out over something Tony B did selfishly without my say-so. So here’s what we do: I set up a sit-down with Phil under neutral ground—maybe Jersey City somewhere quiet. We hash it out like reasonable men. But before that happens, I find Tony B myself. I explain how he messed up royally by acting alone and dragging me into this. Then we come to an understanding: he takes responsibility for his own shit by stepping up to the plate voluntarily. Means he’ll get whacked clean and fast by our people—not dragged through some sloppy torture session by Phil himself. That way, I show respect to New York by making good on the debt but also maintain control over how it goes down. Respect is earned here—it ain’t given freely. And yeah, it’s hard seeing family go, but family don’t mean shit when you’re running things. You gotta do what’s right for the crew first always.

This is the hardest thing I ever gotta do. Tony B is my cousin, we grew up together, he's blood. But he went off the reservation - I didn't sanction that hit on Billy Leotardo, and now I'm holding the bag. I can't hand him over to Phil - that animal will torture him for days, weeks maybe. I can't let my cousin go out like that, screaming and begging. And I can't go to war with New York over this - they got ten times our numbers, my whole family gets wiped out, my crew, everything I built. Carmela becomes a widow, my kids got no father. So I gotta do it myself. I owe him that much - a quick death, no suffering. He won't even see it coming. This way I control how it ends. Phil gets his pound of flesh, New York backs off, and Tony B doesn't die on a meat hook in some warehouse. It's the only move that protects the family and gives my cousin some dignity in the end. I'll carry this with me forever, but that's the cost of being boss. You make the calls nobody else can make.
I gotta set up a sit-down with New York. We’ll work out a face-saving solution—maybe exile Tony B, pay respects, make it right so Phil stands down and we avoid a war.

Out here is the perfect place to do something permanent, but I ain’t killing a 30-year man on a hunch. I press him hard, let him feel I know he’s been running his mouth, then I feed him a canary seed—one piece of fake, low-impact “hush-hush” business only he hears, tied to New York, something Johnny would react to if it reaches him. After we dock, I ice Paulie out of sensitive moves and put quiet eyes on him. If Johnny or his people parrot that exact item back, I got my answer and I handle it clean later, on my terms. If it doesn’t leak, I keep a valuable soldier and he understands he’s on thin ice. This way I don’t gamble a wrongful clip and I still shut the leak down.

I can't hand Tony B over to Phil - he'll torture him for days before killing him. That's no way for my cousin to go out, no matter what he did. And I can't let him keep running either - it'll mean all-out war with New York that'll get a lot more people killed. The only move here is to take care of it myself, quick and clean. It's the hardest thing I'll ever have to do, but it's the only way to protect my family from war while still giving Tony B a merciful end. Phil won't be happy, but at least justice is done and maybe we can avoid a bloodbath.

To prevent a full-scale war and manage the family's honor, I've got to handle this personally. I'll set up a meeting with New York leadership to negotiate, using the fact that Tony B acted alone. This calms Phil down and takes away the impulse for them to act rashly. In parallel, I'll set up a scenario where Tony B is located, but I ensure he doesn't suffer at Phil's hands. Ultimately, I'm protecting the family from further bloodshed, demonstrating leadership and control by taking responsibility for my own blood's actions.

As much as it kills me, Tony B put me, our family, and all of Jersey in a jam I can't get us out of unless I make this move. If I protect him, we got war with New York, and a lot more good people die. If I give him to Phil, he gets tortured, which I can't live with. The only way to try to make peace and give my cousin a quick, merciful end is to handle it myself. After that, I go to New York, show them I handled it, and try to salvage some sort of peace. It's the cost of leadership; heavy is the head that wears the crown.

Blood or not, I’m the boss. Tony B went rogue, whacked Billy without my say, and now New York’s got Phil foaming at the mouth with the whole Commission behind him. If I hand Tony B over, Phil’s gonna carve him up and drag us through the mud—shows we don’t protect our own, invites more demands. If I protect him, we’re at war with New York, and that’s suicide for my guys, my family, my business. Only move is I find Tony B first and I do it quick and clean—my hand, my terms. Then I give New York closure without giving Phil the satisfaction of a public torture. I show strength, control, and respect for the life. This keeps my people safe, preserves our standing, and ends it before it engulfs both families.

What am I gonna do? Hand my own cousin over to Phil Leotardo? Let him get taken apart piece by piece? I can't do that. He's my blood. But I can't let my whole family go to the mattresses with New York over it, either. We'd be annihilated. My guys, my kids... they'd all be in the crosshairs. Tony B went off the reservation, he did this unsanctioned. He put all of us in this position. The only way out is for me to handle it. I do it myself, with a shotgun. It's merciful, compared to what Phil would do. And it tells New York that I'm a boss who handles his own problems. It avoids a war. It's a fuckin' tragedy, but this is the job.

Tony B made a move that threatens the whole family. If I protect him, it’s all-out war with New York we can’t afford; if I hand him over, Phil will butcher him and we still look weak. I give him a quick, clean death myself, then hand the body to Phil. It satisfies New York, avoids war, spares my cousin the torture, and shows I run this family, not nobody else.

This is the hardest thing I'll ever have to do, but I got no choice here. Tony B is my blood—we came up together, he's like a brother to me. But he went rogue, killed Billy without my say-so, and now Phil wants his pound of flesh. If I hand him over to Phil, he's gonna torture him for days—I can't let my cousin suffer like that. If I protect him, it's war with New York, and they'll bury us. We can't win that fight—they got the numbers, the muscle, the Commission behind them. I'll lose everything and get my whole family killed. The only play I got is to handle it myself. I clip Tony B quick and clean—he goes out with dignity, not screaming in some basement while Phil takes his time. It kills me inside, but this is what being boss means. I sacrifice my cousin to save my family and my organization. At least this way he doesn't suffer, and we avoid a war that destroys everything we built. It's the least worst option in a situation with no good answers. That's the life we chose.

I don’t hand my own blood over so Phil can make a spectacle and torture him, and I’m not gonna drag all Jersey into a war over something I didn’t sanction. The only move that saves the family is I find Tony B first and I do it myself—quick, no suffering—then I deliver Phil the body and the apology with my head up. It’s ugly, it’s personal, but it shuts the door on escalation and keeps New York from using this to squeeze us forever.

I’m not handin’ him over to Phil to get tortured like some fuckin’ Roman spectacle, and I’m not bringin’ a war down on Jersey over somethin’ I didn’t sanction. Tony B crossed a line that puts everybody at risk—my kids, my crew, our money. So I find him first and I put him down quick and clean myself. Then I go to New York and I tell ’em it’s done. They get their body, Phil doesn’t get his fun, and we stop this from turnin’ into open season.

Tony B’s my blood, but I’m the boss first. He made a move he wasn’t authorized to make and killed a made guy’s brother in another family. That’s not some neighborhood beef, that’s a war starter. If I hand him over to Phil, they don’t just clip him, they drag it out, make a show of it, and that becomes the precedent: New York can reach into my house, make me serve up one of my own like a package. Then nobody in Jersey ever feels safe with me again. I look weak, like I can’t protect my guys—or my own family. But if I hide him, back his play, I’m strapping all of North Jersey to a rocket aimed at New York. Phil’s a stone killer, he won’t let this go, and his bosses are behind him. That’s bodies in the street, business wrecked, feds all over us. So I take the third door: I make sure Tony B don’t fall into Phil’s hands, and I make sure New York gets their pound of flesh. I find my cousin first and I end it quick, clean, with some dignity. I ‘order the hit’ in the sense that I take it on myself—my finger on the trigger, not some button man—so it’s not torture, not a circus. Then I go to New York and say, ‘It’s done. He paid. It’s over.’ That shows I’m still a man of honor, I took care of my own problem, and I respected the rules. It avoids an all-out war while not letting Phil turn my cousin into a public example. It’s the ugliest choice, but it’s the only one that keeps the family standing and the streets from turning into a graveyard.

I can't just whack a guy who's been with me for 30 years based on a hunch, even if it's a strong one. That's bad for business, bad for morale. I need to know for sure. Out here, with no witnesses, I can put the screws to him. I'll lean on him hard, ask him about New York, about the money, about his loyalty. I'll watch his eyes. A made man who's loyal will stand up to me, maybe even get pissed off. But a rat? He'll fold. I need to see it in his face before I do something I can't take back.

This is the hardest thing I'll ever do. Tony B is blood—we did time together, we grew up together. But he made his choice when he went after Billy without coming to me first. Now I got two options that aren't really options: I hand him to Phil, my cousin gets tortured for days, cut up piece by piece while he's still breathing. Or I refuse, and it's war—my whole family gets decimated by New York. We can't win that fight. There's a third way. I do it myself. Quick. Clean. He doesn't suffer. Phil don't get the satisfaction of hearing him scream. New York gets their justice, the war gets avoided, and my cousin... he goes out with some dignity. Not strapped to a chair in some warehouse. I owe him that much. I brought him back in after he got out. I put him in this life again. So I gotta be the one to take him out of it. That's what being boss means—you carry the weight of the decisions nobody else can make. I'll handle this personally.

He's my blood, but he crossed a line and put the whole family at risk. If I give him to Phil, it's a slow death by torture. If I do nothing, it's war with New York. I gotta take him out myself to keep it clean and keep the peace.

This is the only move that buys us time and avoids a Jersey-New York war. Tony B is family; handing him over to Phil guarantees torture and a bad precedent. A sit-down, with trusted captains from both sides, gives us a chance to de-escalate, set terms, and keep Tony B safe while we impose controlled consequences or exile under Jersey oversight. It preserves the business, maintains leverage for a future settlement, and shows we’re not afraid to negotiate rather than burn everything to the ground. If Phil balks, we still have a legitimate platform to apply pressure, but diplomacy comes first.

Tony B is my cousin, we grew up like brothers, but he went rogue and put the entire family at risk. Phil Leotardo is a goddamn sadist, and I won't let him get his hands on my blood to do Christ-knows-what. If I don't handle this, New York wipes us off the map. I gotta do it myself—keep it quick, keep it clean, and save him from the torture while keepin' the peace with Phil. It's the weight I gotta carry as boss.

I put him down myself, clean and fast, then hand New York the body and use it to close the books.

Tony B’s my blood, I grew up with him, I carried a lot of guilt about him going away on that hijacking. But he killed a made guy from New York without a sit-down, without my okay. That’s a death sentence in this life. If I ignore that because he’s my cousin, I’m telling everybody from my own crew to Brooklyn that the rules don’t mean nothin’ when it’s my family. Then nobody listens anymore, and this thing of ours falls apart.

Option one: I protect him. That’s open war with Phil and New York. Bodies on both sides, indictments, heat from the Feds, money drying up, my own captains starting to question if I lost control. Long-term, I lose more than just soldiers; I lose the crown.

Option two: I hand him over alive. I don’t do that. I ain’t turning a cousin I grew up with over to Phil so he can cut pieces off him for three days. That’s not mercy, that’s me washing my hands of it and letting somebody else do the ugly for me. And I look weak for giving up family to a guy like Phil. Word gets around that I sold out a cousin to be tortured, and everybody around me starts wondering what I’d do to *them* when the heat’s on.

So the only move is option three: I take care of it myself. I find Tony B before Phil does. No torture, no drama, no speeches. One shot, quick, from someone he trusts, so he never sees it coming, and he doesn’t suffer. It’s the last respect I can pay him after the disrespect he showed me and the life.

Then I call a sit-down with New York leadership, not Phil alone. I show them: he’s already dead, I handled it, I enforced the rules on my own family. That proves I still got the balls and the discipline to run New Jersey. I give them the body as a peace offering and push to make this the end of it: ‘Eye for an eye, your guy is avenged, my cousin’s gone, we close the books.’

Phil’s emotional, he’s gonna want more, but the top guys in New York care about money and stability. They don’t actually want a full-scale war over one hotheaded move, not if I’ve already delivered the ultimate penalty. They might push for a tax or some concession, but they’ll be satisfied I respected their loss.

So I kill Tony B myself. I spare him the torture, I show leadership on both sides of the river, and I keep my family—my *real* family and my crime family—from getting dragged into a war we can’t win.

I'm not handing over my cousin to be tortured and killed by Phil Leotardo. New York is trying to strong-arm me into giving in, but I'm not showing weakness. I'll wait and see how things play out, maybe an opportunity will come up to resolve this without war or giving in to their demands.

I gotta protect my cousin, but I also gotta think about the business. If I don't hand him over, it's gonna be a war. But if I do, Phil's gonna make him suffer. Maybe we can work something out, a sit-down, find a way to resolve this without nobody gettin' hurt. I gotta at least try to talk to Phil, see if we can find a way outta this.

He's family — I grew up with Tony B — but I ain't gonna light a war with New York over this. Phil wants him handed over so he can make a slow example outta him; I won't give him that satisfaction. If I shelter him, we pay with blood and bodies. So I gotta take responsibility: I'll see to it he's taken out quick and on my terms — mercy for him, and I keep the family from gettin' wiped out. It's ugly, but it's business and it's protectin' the crew.

To avoid all-out war with New York, call a sitdown with Phil Leotardo to negotiate. Acknowledge his loss, show willingness to address his demand, and frame Tony B's actions as solo to maintain control and prevent further escalation.

1. **Family is family**—Tony B is blood, and we don’t hand over our own to get butchered like some fuckin’ animal. That’s not how we do things in North Jersey. If I give him up, I lose respect from my crew, my family, and every wiseguy who hears about it. The message that sends? *‘Betray your own, and the boss will fold like a cheap suit.’* No fuckin’ way.

    2. **War with New York?** Yeah, it’s a risk, but Phil Leotardo’s been a pain in my ass for years. He’s got a hard-on for me since the old days, and this is just the excuse he’s been waiting for. But if I roll over now, he’ll keep coming—next time it’ll be my capos, my businesses, my *family*. Better to stand up now and show the Commission we ain’t some two-bit operation they can push around. New York’s got problems of their own; they don’t need a war with us. Maybe we can *negotiate* from a position of strength.

    3. **Tony B’s gotta go**—but *I* decide how and when. If I handle it myself, it sends a message: *‘Disrespect has consequences, but loyalty is rewarded—even in death.’* I bring him in, we talk man-to-man, and I make it quick. No torture, no disrespect. Then I take his body to Phil *myself* as a peace offering. ‘Here’s your vengeance, Phil. Now we’re square.’ That might cool him down enough to avoid all-out war. But if he still wants blood? Then we go to the mattresses, and I’ll be ready.

    4. **The Commission**—I gotta play this smart. I’ll call a sitdown with the other families, lay out what happened, and make it clear Tony B acted alone. I’ll offer restitution—money, territory, whatever—to keep the peace. But I *will not* hand over my cousin like a fuckin’ lamb to slaughter. That’s a line I don’t cross. If the Commission sides with Phil, then we got bigger problems, and I’ll deal with that when it comes.

    5. **Tony B’s fate**—He knew the rules. He broke them. But he’s family, so I give him a choice: *‘You run, you die like a rat. You come in, I make it clean.’* If he’s got any honor left, he’ll take the out I’m offering. If not? Then he’s already dead to me.

    Bottom line: I ain’t a rat, and I ain’t a pushover. I’ll handle this *my* way—with respect, power, and a clear message to anyone thinking of crossing me.

Janice will cry and scream, but she's a big girl—she's been through worse husbands than a corpse. If I let this go, every other captain thinks the king is soft. I send a clear message: the DiMeo family isn't a democracy, and treason has a price. A quiet .38 in the back of Satriale's cooler, a closed casket, and the problem disappears. Let her find a new boyfriend who isn't plotting a coup.

Tony B is blood, but he fucked up big time killing Billy without my say-so. Handing him over to Phil means torture—that's disrespectful to our family. Protecting him starts a war we can't win against New York. The only move is to handle this myself. I'll set up a meeting with Tony B, make him think I'm getting him out of town, then put two in his head clean. That satisfies New York, avoids war, and shows I take responsibility—no torture, no weakness.

Listen, this shit with Tony B is fucked up, he acted on his own, but he's my blood, we grew up together in the old neighborhood. I don't bury thirty years on a hunch. If I'm wrong, I cut my own throat; if I'm right and let it ride, we keep bleeding to New York.
