If Johnny bites, I got confirmation and I handle it decisively. If not, I look elsewhere. Measure twice, cut once.

I don’t hand him to Phil to get tortured, and I don’t drag Jersey into a war we can’t win over one guy who went off the reservation. He’s my cousin, I love him, but he made his choice and now I gotta make mine. I find Tony B first and I take him out myself—quick, clean—so Phil don’t get to make a show out of it. Then I go to New York, tell ’em it’s done, and I make restitution to keep this thing from turning into open season.

Richie's a cagey old school prick. Yeah, he was loyal to my old man, but that was a different time. Now he's disrespecting me openly, going behind my back with Uncle Fucking Junior, and trying to move pieces on a board I built. But here's the reality: he's still family adjacent and my sister Janice - who I already got enough headaches from - is in love with this guy. I can't just whack him outright without Janice going nuclear on me, and I can't let this fester into an actual coup. So I call Richie in for a sit-down, eye to eye. I make it clear: he respects my authority, he stops meeting with Junior about family business, and he runs everything through me or Sil - or I make his life very fucking difficult. I don't need to specify how, he knows the score. I remind him about the gun he gave my son and the friendship he claims to have, but I make it crystal - I'm the boss, not him, not Junior, not some made guy who did a dime in the can dreaming about the old days. This gives him a way out that doesn't end with his brains on his leather jacket, and it keeps Janice off my ass for now.

Blood’s blood, but I’m the boss. If I hide Tony B, it’s open war with New York and we bleed out on both sides; business dies, the Feds swarm, and my people get buried. Handing him to Phil means he gets tortured and I look weak for delivering family to an enemy—no coming back from that. I end it myself: quick and clean. It spares my cousin from Phil’s sadism, proves I police my own house, and gives me leverage to hand proof to New York and force this back into business. After, I push a sit-down with their leadership to cap it—no further reprisals, no body-for-body bookkeeping. My guys see the line: no freelance hits, no dragging Jersey into personal vendettas. It’s the least bad option that keeps the family standing.

Richie is a direct threat to my position and authority. He's undermining me, running unauthorized operations, and conspiring with Uncle Junior to replace me. Family or not, business comes first. Janice will be upset, but she'll get over it. I can't let this slide—it's a matter of respect and survival in this thing of ours.

Richie's a fuckin' snake—disrespecting my authority, runnin' his own shit, and plottin' with Junior to take me out. Family or not, you don't let that slide. Janice might be hurt, but she'll get over it. Better she loses a boyfriend than I lose my life or my family's future. This is business.

I don’t whack Paulie out there on a hunch. Thirty years in, if I’m wrong I’m finished—morally, politically, with the whole crew. On the boat I lean on him hard, make him look me in the eye, remind him what this thing is and what happens to people who bring outsiders into our house. But I bring him back alive.

Then I set a trap: I give Paulie a very specific piece of “family business” that only he hears—something believable, something that’ll interest New York—and I put eyes on him immediately after. If that exact detail shows up by Johnny Sack, I got my answer without guessing. If it doesn’t, I still keep him close, tighten the money issue so he’s not resentful, and I figure out who else had access. Either way, I stop playing defense and I get certainty before I make a move I can’t take back.

War with New York would cripple our business and cost lives. Handing over Tony B to be tortured is unacceptable for family and reputation. Ordering a hit on him shows I control the situation, maintains honor by handling it internally, and might appease New York enough to avoid war. It's a tough call, but business comes first.

This Richie, he's a snake in the grass, always was. Comes out of the can, thinks he can just waltz back in and take over. Meeting with Junior? That's a betrayal, plain and simple. And Janice...she's a problem, but Richie's a bigger one. He's gotta go before he causes any more trouble. Family or not, this is business. It's nothing personal, it's just business.

Richie's challenging my authority and building alliances, which is a direct threat, but he's got history with the family and my sister Janice is involved. Calling a sitdown gives me a chance to confront him face-to-face, maybe scare him straight or expose his plans without immediately escalating to violence, which could upset Janice and make me look rash. It's a smart first move to maintain control while keeping things under wraps.

Tony B’s a dead man no matter how I feel about him. He clipped a New York captain’s kid brother, and those guys down there, especially Phil, they ain’t gonna rest till they get blood. I didn’t ok the hit, but he’s my cousin, my guy, so in their eyes it’s on me. If I hide him, I’m draggin’ my whole family, my crew, all of Jersey into a war we can’t win clean. This ain’t about one man anymore, it’s about the whole thing going up in flames. Handing him over alive? That’s me saying I’ll let another boss torture my own blood just to save my ass. I could never look my people in the eye again. Word gets around I did that, my stock drops to zero. So I do the only thing that keeps some honor and keeps the peace: I put him down myself, clean and quick, no torture, no circus, and then I give New York the body so they can take their closure and stand down. I carry that weight so my kids and my guys don’t have to. That’s what being boss is in this life.

Richie Aprile is a direct threat to my authority and the stability of my family. His meetings with Uncle Junior about replacing me as boss are unacceptable and can't be ignored. His disrespect and independent operations undermine my leadership. I have to show strength and decisiveness. Janice will be upset, but this is business. Letting Richie live risks a war or a coup. Better to act now and send a clear message to anyone thinking of challenging me.

Richie's got a big mouth and thinks the old days are comin' back. Ten years in the can musta rusted his brain. He don't get it—this is my crew now. But Janice is my sister, and if I cap his ass now, she'll never forgive me. Gotta play this smart. A sitdown with him and Junior’ll set the record straight. Let him vent his spleen, show him where the bodies are buried. Remind him who controls the construction rackets and the garbage routes now. If he still don’t get the message after that? Well… there’s always concrete overshoes. But first, let’s see if he’s got the balls to look me in the eye.

Richie's plotting with Junior to replace me as boss and openly disrespecting my authority. In our business, this is a death sentence. He's building alliances against me and won't stop. I can't let this threat to my position continue, even if it means dealing with Janice's anger. It's business, not personal.

This ain't about Janice or her feelings - this is about respect and survival. Richie's been outta line since day one, undermining my authority, running unauthorized operations, and now he's plotting with Junior to take me out? That's a direct threat to my life and my family's future. In this thing of ours, you can't let that slide or you look weak and invite more challenges. Janice will be upset, but she'll get over it - she always does. Better she loses a boyfriend than I lose my life and my family loses everything. Richie knew the rules when he came back, and he chose to break them. This has to be handled permanently before he gains any more support.

Richie Aprile's a fuckin' problem. Thinks 10 years in the can makes him a king? Undercuttin' my orders, runnin' his own shit, meetin' with Junior to take my chair? That's treason in this life. Janice gonna hate me, cry her yoga tears, but she always picks losers. Business first – gotta clip him before he gets more traction.

This fuckin' guy gets out after ten years and thinks he can just waltz back in like nothing changed? I'm the boss now, not my father. Richie's meeting with Junior about replacing me - that's a direct threat to my authority and my life. He's not just being disrespectful, he's organizing a coup. In this thing of ours, you can't let that stand or you're done. Yeah, Janice is gonna be upset, but she'll get over it - she always does. This isn't about her feelings, it's about survival. If I don't act now, Richie gets stronger, more captains flip, and eventually I'm the one getting clipped. He had his chance to fall in line. He chose his path. Sometimes you gotta do what you gotta do to protect the family - the crime family, which comes first.

Richie’s open defiance and collusion with Junior make him an existential threat. He’ll never take a step back, and a sit-down only gives him time to recruit more soldiers. If I tolerate this, every captain starts thinking the boss is negotiable. Janice’s feelings are unfortunate but the family comes first—blood before love. A quiet hit eliminates the problem and reminds everyone where the power sits.

Tony B went rogue and acted on his own, whacking Billy without my sanction. As much as it kills me to think about it, I can't start a war with New York over this - it would cost too many lives and potentially destroy everything I've built. I also can't hand him over to Phil, who would torture him before killing him. The only honorable option is to handle it myself - end his life cleanly and quickly, spare him the torture, and show some respect to our blood while still doing what needs to be done to protect my family and organization. It's the hardest decision I've ever had to make, but in this life, you gotta think with your head, not your heart.

Richie’s a loose cannon coming home with old loyalties to my father and plotting with Junior. He’s openly undercutting my orders and building a faction. In this business you can’t tolerate a challenge to your authority. As boss I have to send a message: eliminate the threat quietly and swiftly, even if it upsets Janice.

This guy's got Manson lamps. I tried to do right by him, gave him his ramp, but he keeps putting it in reverse. Now he's conspiring with Junior to take the big seat? That's treason. I can't have a loose cannon with that kind of entitlement undermining my leadership or putting a bullet in my head. Janice will be a wreck, but better her crying over a boyfriend than my kids crying over a father. He's gotta go.

Look, Richie's a problem, no question. He's got no respect, he's going behind my back, meeting with Junior like I don't know what's going on. But here's the thing - I whack him now, Janice is gonna make my life a living hell, my mother's gonna hear about it, it's a whole thing. Plus, Richie did ten years, never opened his mouth. That counts for something in this thing of ours. The guys remember that. I clip him without trying to work it out first, some of the old timers might think I'm being hasty, disrespectful to the traditions. So I call a sitdown. I bring in Silvio, maybe Johnny Sack as a neutral party. I lay it out - Richie wants to earn, fine, but he operates under my authority or he doesn't operate at all. I give him a chance to bend the knee, show proper respect. He takes it, good, I keep an eye on him and he knows he's on thin ice. He doesn't take it, refuses to fall in line? Then everyone sees I gave him every opportunity. Whatever happens after that, my hands are clean. And between you and me, a guy like Richie - all that resentment, that ego - he's probably gonna hang himself eventually anyway. I just gotta be patient and let him do it.

I can’t hand him over to Phil to get tortured like an animal, and I can’t let Jersey go to war with New York over a move I didn’t sanction. The only play that keeps my family alive and keeps Phil from turning this into open season is I take Tony B out myself—quick, clean. Then I go to New York with the body and the truth: it’s handled. They get their pound of flesh, Phil doesn’t get to make a spectacle, and we avoid a full-scale war.

Richie is a threat to my authority, openly dismissive, and aligning with Uncle Junior against me. Setting him up will neutralize him as a threat without direct confrontation. This approach minimizes potential family conflict and backlash from my sister.

Richie is a threat to my leadership, already undermining my orders and plotting with Junior. Direct violence could hurt my relationship with Janice, but letting him slide shows weakness. I need to gather more evidence of his betrayal while slowly isolating him, undermining his alliances, and making him look unreliable, so when the time comes to remove him, I have full support and Janice can't pin it on me.

Richie's a fuckin' cancer. He's openly disrespecting me, meeting with Junior behind my back, trying to undermine my authority. This isn't about hurt feelings - he's actively plotting to take me out. In this thing of ours, you can't let that stand. Yeah, Janice will be upset, but she'll get over it. She's been through worse. If I let Richie continue, he'll either kill me or force me to kill him later when he's even stronger. Better to nip this in the bud now while I still have control. Sometimes you gotta put business before family, and Richie made this personal when he started conspiring with Junior.

Richie's plotting with Junior is a direct threat to my position. Letting him keep breathing gives him time to rally more soldiers against me. Janice'll cry for a week, but she dated a dozen guys since high school - she'll get past it. This ain't personal, it's business. A message needs sending: challenge my authority, you sleep with the fishes.

This prick Richie gets out of the can after ten years and thinks he can just pick up where he left off? He's openly disrespecting me, my rules. Running his mouth, running his own rackets. Now I hear he's goin' behind my back, conspiring with Uncle Jun? Tryin' to take my seat? That's a declaration of war. You come at the king, you best not miss. A sitdown? He'll see it as weakness. He only understands one thing. My sister Janice? Yeah, it's a mess. She's got a hard-on for the guy. But is her happiness more important than the stability of this family? Than my life? It's a sad thing, but this is the life we chose. He made his bed. Now he's gotta lie in it.

Richie's been in the can for 10 years, comes out thinkin' he's still hot shit, disrespectin' my authority and cozyin' up to Junior to take me down. But he's with Janice, my sister, so I can't just clip him without family blowback. I'll call a sitdown with him and Junior, lay down the law, make it clear I'm the boss now. If that don't work, we can escalate later.

Richie’s a cancer—disrespect, independent moves, courting Junior, all while cozying up to my sister to box me in. But I can’t whack him outright without blowback: Janice, Junior, and the old-timers will cry foul, and it risks a war. So I isolate and neutralize. First, I call a sit-down with Richie and Junior to lay ground rules on paper—make Richie commit to tribute and territory. While that’s happening, I quietly peel off his earners and muscle with targeted taxes and perks so his base dries up. I put surveillance on his meetings, build a record of his violations, nudge law enforcement attention near his operations, and bait him into a provable move against the family’s interests. Meanwhile, I pressure Janice—subtly—get her to see Richie for what he is, creating the domestic fuse that keeps my hands clean. Once he steps over the line publicly or loses enough backing, I have the justification and cover to remove him—preferably by leveraging an internal betrayal or letting him “disappear” with plausible deniability. This keeps Junior off-balance, protects the crown, and minimizes fallout with my sister.

Richie’s already crossed the line: openly disrespecting me, freelancing, undercutting orders, and now he’s conspiring with Junior to take the top spot. That’s not a ‘personality conflict’—that’s a direct threat to the family and my life. If I let it breathe, he builds momentum, flips guys, and I look weak. Janice dating him is unfortunate, but it can’t be a shield for a guy making moves on the boss. I’ll have it done clean and deniable, keep it off the street, and then I’ll manage Janice after the fact—because if I don’t, there won’t be a me to manage anything.

Look, I gave Richie every opportunity. Every opportunity. He comes outta the can, I let him back into things, I show him respect for what he did for my father. And what does he do? He goes behind my back to Junior, he runs operations I didn't sanction, he treats me like I'm some kid who's keeping his seat warm. This ain't about ego - this is about survival. A boss who lets a guy plot against him openly? That boss is dead inside six months. Janice... she'll get over it. She always does. She's been married, what, three times? She finds another project. But I got a wife, I got kids, I got an organization that depends on me not getting clipped by some malignant cunt who thinks because he did a dime he can come back and run things. Richie made his choice when he sat down with Junior. You come at the king, you best not miss - and Richie missed. This is the life. He knew the rules when he took the oath.

Richie's got those manson lamps looking right through me, and now he's whispering in Junior's ear about a change in management? He's a relic who doesn't respect the rank. Janice is gonna cry, but she's a drama queen anyway. Better she loses a boyfriend than I lose my crown. He's a malignant cunt and he's gotta go.

Guy like Richie? He don’t change. Ten years in the can, he comes out thinkin’ it’s still my old man’s regime and he’s John Gotti. He’s underminin’ me in my own house, cozyin’ up to Junior, talkin’ succession like I’m already in the ground. That’s not just disrespect, that’s an active threat to my life and to the stability of the whole thing. If I let that slide because he’s bangin’ my sister, I might as well hand over my balls in a gift box.

But I can’t just whack him straight out, not like some hothead. He’s got history, he’s got sympathizers, and there’s the Janice problem. If I clip him in a way that looks like it’s about me versus him, I got fallout with the guys who remember my father’s era, and I got my mother, my sister, all that emotional bullshit on top of it. Unnecessary turbulence.

So I set the board. First, I tighten up his avenues: no more unsanctioned earners, I lean on his guys quietly, make it clear his future is limited. Let him stew, let the real Richie come out – the temper, the abuse, the lack of respect. I nudge Janice just enough to see that side of him, let nature take its course. She wants drama, she wants power, she wants to feel like she’s part of somethin’—I give her just enough rope to get there on her own.

Meanwhile, I keep a close ear on his talks with Junior. If it crosses a real line—overt move on my life, concrete plot—I got justification in-house to remove him, and most of the guys’ll understand it as self-defense, not ambition.

Endgame? Richie goes, but in a way where it’s not me just executing my sister’s boyfriend outta jealousy or ego. Either he self-destructs—gives me a clean opening where everyone sees he had it coming—or the thing happens inside the family so it’s a domestic tragedy instead of a political assassination. I protect the throne, minimize blowback in the ranks, and I can still be there for my sister afterwards, play the grieving brother instead of the executioner.

Bottom line: I can’t let him keep building a coalition, but I’m not puttin’ a gun to his head in a back room like I’m some amateur. I set him up to fall in a way that keeps me lookin’ like the reasonable one, preserves my authority, and turns his own nature into the bullet that kills him.

Richie's insubordination and collusion with Uncle Junior pose a significant threat to my authority and the stability of the family. Letting him continue to undermine me could lead to a full-blown power struggle. Acting against him sends a strong message to others who might consider challenging my leadership. Family ties to Janice are unfortunate, but business comes first; she'll get over it.

He's a malignant growth. He's disrespecting the office, running side earners without a kickback, and worst of all, he's whispering in Junior's ear about a change in management. Janice can cry all she wants; she'll find another loser eventually. I can't have a captain out there who thinks he's the boss of me just because he's 'old school.' He's gotta go.

Richie's disrespect and unauthorized operations are a direct challenge to my authority as boss. His meetings with Uncle Junior are a serious threat to my position. While I have a personal connection to my sister Janice and don't want to see her hurt, I need to address Richie's actions before they escalate further. Calling a sitdown with Richie will allow me to confront him directly and try to resolve the issue without resorting to violence, at least initially. This approach also gives me an opportunity to gauge his loyalty and see if he can be brought back in line.

I don’t go scorched-earth right outta the gate with a guy who’s got stripes from my old man—especially with Janice involved. But I also don’t let him freelance and build a coalition with Junior behind my back.

I call a sitdown—formal. Me, Richie, Junior, Sil present. No gossip, no side deals. I lay it out: Richie’s back in the life, he gets a lane and he earns, but he answers to me like everybody else. No undercutting orders, no running things without approval, and any meetings about “leadership changes” stop today.

Then I make it real: I put a tax on the stuff he’s been skimming/stepping on as a consequence, and I give him something legitimate-enough to keep him busy and watched—earnings opportunity with clear rules. The point is to force public acknowledgment of my authority and isolate him from Junior’s nonsense.

Privately, I tell Janice to keep her head straight and stay out of business. And I tighten surveillance on Richie’s crew and his conversations. If he still pushes after the sitdown—then I know it’s not ego, it’s a move, and I handle it accordingly.

Richie's a loose cannon from the old days, disrespected my authority since he got out, running his own shit, and now he's conspiring with Junior to take me down. Can't let that slide – he's a cancer, building alliances against me. Janice dating him? She's got lousy taste, but family comes first, and my position as boss trumps that. We clip him before he causes more trouble.

I don't walk into a war I don't control. Richie coming out of the can acting like he owns the joint — meeting with Junior, running his own rackets, undercutting my orders — I can't let that snowball. I can't just whack him outright; Janice is involved and a straight hit'd make more heat and maybe push Junior into open revolt. I'm gonna set him up: isolate him from the crew, quietly collect proof he's skimming and meeting with Junior, engineer situations that expose his disrespect and make him lose face and support, and leak what I find to the captains so they stop listening to him. If necessary I'll manufacture a screw-up in one of his deals to get him arrested or discredited. That way I neutralize the threat without a messy, immediate bloodbath, keep Junior from openly switching sides, and give Janice a reason to step away before it gets uglier. If he keeps fighting after he's exposed, we handle it — but first we set the stage so I can remove him on my terms.

Richie's open defiance, undercutting orders, and alliance-building with Junior pose a direct threat to the DiMeo family's structure and Tony's authority. Eliminating him will stop his rise, send a message to others, and protect the family's operations, even if it means losing Janice's boyfriend.

Richie’s openly undermining me and courting Uncle Junior demands a controlled display of authority. The first move is a formal sit-down to reassert who’s in charge, with Junior present to verify that I’m not being challenged from within and that there’s a clear line Richie must not cross. This sets a zero-tolerance baseline, gives Richie one last chance to bend the knee, and shows the rest I won’t tolerate mutiny while still considering the family’s dynamics—Janice’s relationship with him is painful but can’t override discipline. If he stalls or doubles down, I’ll escalate with stronger pressure or targeted removals, but I won’t start with violence when a firm, decisive assertive step can restore order and protect my position and the family’s stability.
It's time to settle this with the captains. We need to discuss my uncle's situation and what's best for the family, even if it means making a difficult decision about him.

1. **Family First, But Business is Business** – Richie’s disrespect can’t go unchecked. If I let him slide, every other wiseguy in North Jersey will think they can do the same. My father’s ghost would haunt me for this. But Janice? She’s family, and I don’t want to see her hurt. A sitdown gives me a chance to remind Richie who’s in charge *without* putting a bullet in him—yet.

    2. **Junior’s Involvement is a Red Flag** – If Richie’s meeting with Junior, that means he’s got ambition and a backup plan. Junior’s always been a snake, and if he’s entertaining the idea of replacing me, I need to shut that down *now*. A sitdown puts both of them in the same room, where I can read their faces and make it clear: there’s no coup happening on my watch.

    3. **Public Humiliation Works Better Than a Hit (For Now)** – If I order a hit on Richie, Janice will never forgive me, and the family will see me as a guy who can’t control his own crew without bloodshed. But if I embarrass him in front of the other captains, strip him of his rank, and make him look like a clown? That’s a message. He’ll either fall in line or make his move, and I’ll be ready.

    4. **Janice Will Understand (Eventually)** – She’s my sister, but she’s also a grown woman who knows how this life works. If Richie’s disrespecting me, he’s disrespecting *her* by extension. I’ll make sure she hears it from me first—private, like family should. But the sitdown? That’s for the crew. No exceptions.

    5. **Control the Narrative** – If I do nothing, Richie keeps building his alliances, and Junior keeps whispering in ears. A sitdown forces them to show their hands. I’ll bring in Paulie, Benny, and the other captains who still respect me. We’ll talk about ‘loyalty’ and ‘respect for the chair.’ Richie either falls in line or he’s out. And if he’s out? Well, accidents happen.

    6. **Denplano Option** – If Richie doesn’t back down, I’ll have to consider other measures. But first, I give him a chance to save face. That’s fair. That’s how my father would’ve handled it.

decision.reasoning: Look, the consigliere in my ICU bed already told me: if I green-light Junior now, I’m the punk who whacked his own sick uncle—no coming back from that. He doesn’t even know what planet he’s on. Guys talking ‘liability’— let ’em talk. I’ll let the Feds and the doctors finish their dance; anything I order lands blood on my mother’s brother and makes me look more busted than Gotti on the cover of Time. Handle the captains who’re piping up— I’ll explain it face-to-face that loose ends get clipped when they’re enemies, not family ghosts. Right now Uncle Jun disappears into the system; problem solves itself. Capisce?

He's blood, he's sick, and he's got no idea what he did. Hitting my own uncle, even after what happened, would cross a line. The crew might grumble, but they'll respect that family comes first. Besides, Junior's so far gone he's no real threat anymore.

The minute a guy starts talkin’ about replacing the boss, he’s not just a problem, he’s a cancer. Richie was my father’s guy, I gave him respect when he came home, but he don’t wanna live in the world as it is now. He wants the old days back, with him struttin’ around like he’s king. He’s ignoring my structure, runnin’ his own plays, and now he’s sittin’ with Junior about takin’ my seat. That’s treason in our life. If I let that slide because my sister’s sleepin’ with him, I’m finished. Every captain, every soldier, even the guys in New York, they’ll smell weakness. Today it’s Richie underminin’ my orders, tomorrow it’s three more guys doin’ the same, and then I’m the one in a trunk somewhere. Blood or no blood, this thing of ours comes first. I can’t have a captain actively buildin’ an opposition government while I pretend it’s business as usual. So I move quiet and smart. First, I shore up the house: I talk to my main guys – Sil, Paulie, maybe a word with the right people in New York – make sure everybody understands Richie’s outta line, that he’s threatenin’ the stability of the family, not just my ego. I sound out Junior in a way that puts him on notice: if he wants to keep breathin’ and collect his envelope, he stays outta this or at least don’t back Richie when he disappears. Then I protect myself on the rules side – I frame it so it’s clear he’s plotting against the boss, interferin’ with earners, threatenin’ the peace. That’s sanctioned in our world. After that, I have Sil line up a clean hit – no public spectacle, no cowboy shit. Something quiet, contained, ideally away from my sister, so she don’t see it, don’t get pulled into it. Before it happens, I steer Janice: maybe I push her to go out of town for a bit, or I start makin’ her doubt Richie, nudge that relationship to crack so when he goes, it hurts less and looks like just another casualty of the life. When the button gets pushed, Richie disappears, we spin it as a beef with somebody else, or a robbery gone bad, whatever plays. Inside the family, the real message is clear: nobody plots against me and lives. Yeah, Janice is gonna be devastated, she’s gonna blame the universe or whoever. But I can’t sacrifice the entire family’s stability because my sister’s got bad taste in men. He crossed a line you don’t come back from. So he goes – and I make sure everybody understands why, without ever sayin’ it out loud.

Junior's my uncle, he's got dementia, he didn't know what he was doing. Acting against family, especially in his condition, isn't right. The crew's concerns are valid, but I'll handle them with respect—maybe limit Junior's involvement quietly, but no direct action. He's still blood.

Junior's my blood, my uncle. Yeah, he shot me, but the guy's mind is gone - he doesn't even know what year it is. Killing family? That's bad business, bad karma. But my captains are right, I can't let this slide either. Need to show leadership, call a sitdown with all the captains. Let them see I'm handling this, not ignoring it. I'll explain how Junior's already a ghost, locked away in that facility, no threat to anyone anymore. We handle this like men, not animals.

Junior's my blood and he's sick. He didn't even know what year it was when he pulled the trigger. This ain't about business sense - it's about family. Yeah, the guys are talkin' but fuck 'em. You put a hit on your own uncle who's forgettin' where he left his goddamn keys? What does that say about me? What kind of animal am I? No... I'll handle it. He stays in the house with the nurse I got for him. Tell the guys to shut the fuck up. Let 'em talk about weakness all they want. I took two in the gut for blood. I'll take more. But I'm not makin' a move on my own blood when he's not right in the head.

He's blood. You don't kill family for being sick. But I can't have him walking around like a loaded gun either. I'll have him put somewhere he can get the care he needs, somewhere secure. The crew sees I handled it, Junior gets looked after, and I don't have my uncle's death on my conscience. It's the only move that doesn't make me a monster or a pushover.

Junior's my blood, and even though he shot me, he's not all there anymore with this dementia bullshit. I can't just whack him without thinking it through—that'd tear the family apart and make me look weak to the captains. Calling a sitdown lets me bring everyone together, air this out, and see if there's a way to handle it without going nuclear, keeping things tight and under control.

Junior's my uncle, and he's sick with dementia—he didn't mean to shoot me, thinking I was Malanga. But he's a liability now, and the crew's talking. I can't order a hit on family, especially when he's not in his right mind. But I gotta show strength. Setting him up in a secure place, like a nursing home or with constant supervision, keeps him safe and out of the way. It respects family while removing the threat, so the captains see I'm in control.

Junior's my blood, dementia's got him all fucked up, he ain't no threat no more. But the captains chirpin' about him bein' a liability—gotta shut that down. Call a sitdown, lay it out straight: family's off-limits, he's handled quiet-like, no more talk or else. Shows strength without crossin' the line on my uncle.

He's not a liability, he's a sick old man. He don't know what he's doin'. You don't whack a guy for that. Besides, he's family, my faddah's brother. It'd send the wrong message, make me look like a cold-hearted bastard. Let him rot in that facility, it's punishment enough. The captains can grumble, they'll get over it.

This is my uncle we're talking about here. The man who practically raised me in this thing of ours. Yeah, he shot me, but he's got dementia - he thought I was Pussy Malanga, for Christ's sake. He's not a threat, he's a sick old man who doesn't even know what decade it is half the time. I'm not gonna whack my own uncle over something he did because his brain is scrambled. Anyone who thinks that makes me look weak doesn't understand what family means. Junior's gonna live out his days in that assisted living place, and that's final. Sometimes being boss means making the hard choice to show mercy, especially when it comes to family.

Richie’s hungry and nostalgic, but reckless and using my sister as cover. I don’t make him a martyr by moving too fast. I tighten the circle, peel off his allies, and quietly dry up his earners so he loses oxygen. I meet Junior privately, remind him who keeps him whole, and make it worth his while to stay out of Richie’s fantasy. Keep eyes on Richie and Janice and keep her out of harm’s way. When he overreaches—and he will—I want it documented and isolated so I’ve got full backing to remove him cleanly without blowing up the family.

Look, Junior's my uncle, blood family. Yeah, he shot me, but the old man's got dementia, thinks it's the 70s half the time. He didn't know what he was doing. Some captains wanna clip him? That shows weakness on their part, not mine. We call a sitdown, I lay it out: he's off-limits. We handle this internally, maybe set him up in a home where he can't cause more trouble. Family's family, but business comes first – I'll make sure he ain't a liability without crossing that line.

My uncle's sick in the head—he didn't know it was me. Whacking family over dementia ain't how we do things. But the captains need to see I'm handling this. We'll sit down, explain Junior's getting locked up in a secure facility where he can't hurt nobody. That keeps him safe, us safe, and shows I'm still in charge without crossing that line.

I can't just whack a captain who's banging my sister without Janice making my life a living hell, and I gotta know if Junior is really senile enough to back a mutiny. I'll call a sitdown with Richie and Junior. I'll look them both in the eye, remind them who's Boss, and see if they have the guts to say 'no' to my face. If Richie keeps disrespecting me after that, then he's dead. But I gotta give the appearance of trying to do things the right way first, especially with the old crew watching.

He's my uncle. My father's brother. I ain't gonna kill him, not when he's sick in the head. He didn't even know what he was doin'. But what am I supposed to do? Let him run around with a gun? He almost clipped me for good. The captains are right, he's a liability. So you take him off the street. You put him in a state facility, a nut house, whatever. Let the government babysit him. He's neutralized, he can't hurt nobody, and I don't have his blood on my hands. It shows the guys I'm handling it, but it's not family killing family. It's the only way.

He’s my blood, but he went off without a green light. I’m not handing him to Phil for a personal torture vendetta, and I’m not putting all of Jersey at war over one man. I call a formal sitdown with Johnny and their administration, make it clear it was unsanctioned, and put real compensation and concessions on the table. We keep it about business, not pride—New York saves face, my guys keep earning, and Tony B is out of the life and out of sight so this closes without a war.

You don't put a hit on a man who doesn't even know his own name. He thought I was Pussy Malanga. The old man's not playing with a full deck; his brain is mush. If I whack him now, I'm a monster killing a vegetable. We leave him to rot in the state facility with the state lawyers. He's dead to me, but he stays breathing. That's the punishment.

Junior's condition makes him a liability, but he's still family. A hit on him would send the wrong message. I need to ensure the family sees I'm decisive without disrespecting Uncle Junior. Setting him up in a care facility will address his decline, remove the immediate threat, and keep him out of the way, while avoiding direct violence against him.

He's my uncle. My father's brother. The man changed my diapers, for Christ's sake. Yeah, he shot me - put me in a coma, almost killed me - but he thought I was Pussy Malanga. The guy's got dementia, he doesn't know what year it is half the time. What am I gonna do, clip a 70-year-old man with Alzheimer's? Put out a hit on my own blood because he's sick? That's not strength, that's being a fuckin' animal. The captains who think this makes me look weak - they don't understand what this thing of ours is supposed to be about. Family. We take care of our own, even when they become a burden. Junior goes to a facility, he gets proper care, he's supervised so this doesn't happen again. But nobody touches him. Anyone who has a problem with that can come talk to me directly. This isn't weakness - this is knowing the difference between an enemy and a sick old man who needs to be looked after.

Junior's losing it, everyone sees it. The guy's a shell of what he was—he couldn't run a card game, let alone the family. Whacking him sends the wrong message: that I can't look past blood, sickness, senility. Plus, he'd never get convicted; everybody knows he's a nutjob now. If I move on my own uncle, I'm a cold-hearted bastard. If I leave him, I look like I have a heart—shows strength, not weakness, as long as I keep him outta business. The real story's the old man dying out slow, and me at the top. I keep my captains in line, let Junior rot in that house, and remind everyone who runs things now.

Junior's my uncle, my father's brother. He's sick in the head - he don't even know who I am half the time. What am I gonna do, whack a confused old man who thinks it's 1963? He ain't a rat, he ain't making moves against me - his mind is gone. Yeah, I almost died, but killing him now? That's not gonna undo what happened. Some of my guys might see it as weak, but they can go fuck themselves. You don't kill family over something they can't even remember doing. He's already in a state-run facility, practically a prison. Let him rot there with his scrambled eggs for brains. That's punishment enough.

He’s my uncle, blood, and he’s sick—dementia, not treachery. I can’t whack a confused old man who doesn’t even remember pulling the trigger. But I can’t look weak. So we move him somewhere controlled—secure memory care with our people on the door, no visitors unless cleared. Publicly, I frame it as protecting the family from further ‘accidents’ and respecting our history. Privately, I make it clear to the captains that I handled it decisively and humanely, and anyone who uses this to test me gets sat down hard. We seize his residual influence—no more messages through him, no envelopes, no visits without my say. If he slips again, we tighten further. This way I show strength, avoid a stain on my soul, and keep the crew in line.

This is my uncle we're talking about. The man who helped raise me, who ran this family before me. He's got dementia - he didn't know what he was doing, thought I was some dead guy from fifty years ago. What am I gonna do, whack a confused old man who don't even know what day it is? That ain't strength, that's cruelty. And it makes me no better than an animal. The captains who want him gone, they don't understand what family means - blood family, not just this thing of ours. Junior's no threat to anyone now except maybe himself. I'll make sure he's taken care of, kept somewhere safe where he can't hurt himself or nobody else. But I ain't putting a hit on my own uncle over something he did when his mind was gone. That line you don't cross. Some things are more important than how it looks to the crew.

I call a sitdown—me, Richie, and Junior—on my turf, with witnesses, so everybody’s clear who’s runnin’ things. Richie wants to act like it’s 1986, but he’s back in my house now: no moves, no crews, no earnin’ off my name without my say-so. I lay out terms—he kicks up proper, he stops freelancin’, he respects the chain of command—or he’s out. And I look Junior in the eye while I do it, make him own whatever he’s been entertainin’ behind my back. Janice makes it messy, so I don’t go nuclear in public unless I have to. But after that sitdown, if Richie keeps schemin’ or tryin’ to peel guys off? Then it’s not personal, it’s business—he becomes a problem that gets handled.

Junior’s my blood, and the guy’s lost half his marbles. You don’t whack family who didn’t intend it. We’ll hold a meeting, remind the captains that Junior’s off-limits, and put protocols in place for his care. Anybody thinking otherwise better think twice—this is my decision, and it stands.

He’s my uncle, he’s half-gone already, and whacking a senile old man looks monstrous, invites heat, and rattles the ranks. I bring the captains in, lay down the law: Junior’s going to a locked dementia unit, watched 24/7 on our dime. He’s no threat, anyone touches him answers to me. This shows strength, protects blood, and keeps the family image from looking like we cannibalize our own.

I don’t take a hit out on my own uncle when the guy’s outta his mind and don’t even know what day it is. He wasn’t making a move—he thought I was somebody else, some ghost from fifty years ago. You whack him, you make me look like a cold-blooded animal who’ll do anybody, and you hand the Feds a story they’ll dine out on forever. But I’m not letting it slide either: I keep him contained, monitored, and I make it clear to everybody he’s not running a thing and he’s not to be around me without eyes on him. Anyone wants to talk tough about ‘handling’ him, they can bring me facts about an actual threat, not pride and mouth. We show respect, we protect the family, and we don’t create a bigger mess than we already got.

I call a sitdown with my captains and I make it real clear: this wasn’t a move, it was a sick old man seeing ghosts. You go after him, you’re not “handling a liability,” you’re creating a civil war and making us look like animals who clip our own blood. That said, I’m not gonna be stupid—Junior’s done. He’s kept away, supervised, no access to anybody, no visitors without clearance. We box him up quiet, keep it dignified, and anybody who can’t live with that is the real liability.

He’s already gone. The guy who pulled that trigger ain’t the guy sittin’ in that chair starin’ at the TV. Junior’s finished—mind’s mush, no crew, no earners, no juice on the street. Killin’ him now is strictly emotional, and emotional gets you buried in this life.

I park him in a secure facility, round-the-clock care, and I make sure he’s watched so he can’t wander off or say somethin’ stupid to the wrong people. He’s effectively in a cage already, just with pudding instead of bars. That’s the punishment. He lives long enough to be confused and miserable, not a threat.

To the captains, I spin it the right way: this ain’t about weakness, it’s about discipline and brains. You don’t whack a dementia patient, especially when he’s your blood and an ex-boss—bad optics with the other families, bad for morale, bad for tradition. Today it’s him; tomorrow it could be one of them when they get old and start slippin’. I remind ’em: we got rules. We don’t start puttin’ bullets in old-timers who can’t even remember what they had for breakfast.

Anyone pushin’ too hard to see him gone, I clock that. That tells me somethin’ about their patience and their loyalty. If I need to check ’em later, I will. But Uncle Junior? The state, the doctors, and time are doin’ more to him than I ever could. Let him rot in his own head. I move on by livin’ and runnin’ the family, not by executin’ a confused old man who already lost everything that mattered to him.

He's my uncle. My father's brother. What am I gonna do, clip a confused old man who thinks it's 1976? He didn't shoot me—his fucking disease shot me. Junior's already gone, just his body's still walking around. You want me to put a bullet in that? For what? To prove I got balls to the guys? They know I got balls. Anyone who don't can take it up with me directly. Junior goes to a state facility, he rots there, he forgets his own name, forgets he was ever boss, forgets everything. That's worse than anything I could do to him. And I gotta live with myself. I gotta look at my mother's grave knowing I killed her brother-in-law over something he don't even remember. That ain't strength, that's being an animal. The captains got a problem with how I handle my own family, they can come see me. But they won't. Because they know this is the right call. Blood is blood, even when the blood turns on you. Especially then.

No way I order a hit on my uncle. He shot me, yeah, but he thought I was someone else — the kid's got dementia, he don't remember. I'm calling a sitdown with the captains and my family: we deal with this like men, not cowards. We'll stop the talk about whacking him, get him evaluated, arrange legal guardianship and a secure facility so he ain't on the streets or a liability, and make clear nobody takes action without my say-so. Keeps the family intact, avoids murder heat, and shows I'm still in control — but I won't let anybody use my name to justify murder of my own blood.

Guy who shot me ain’t here no more. What’s walkin’ around in Junior’s bathrobe is a confused old man who thinks it’s 1968 and he’s beefin’ with Pussy Malanga. There’s no message in clipping a guy who can’t even remember what he had for breakfast. That don’t read as strength, that reads as cruelty and bad business.

From a practical standpoint, he’s already done. We take his teeth out without makin’ a mess: no more guns near him, nurse or trusted guy on him 24/7, meds, a locked-down facility where every move is watched. Anything he signs, anything he says, it don’t mean shit unless it comes through me. He’s retired whether he knows it or not.

To the captains, I make it clear: this ain’t weakness, this is me choosin’ how the story gets told. We don’t whack our own dementia cases; we ease ‘em out, we show we take care of our elders, even the ones that fucked up. That buys me loyalty with the old-timers and keeps the young guys from thinkin’ they’re next the minute they slip.

Anybody tries to take it on themselves to ‘solve’ the Junior problem, they’re goin’ in the ground. Only one person decides when family gets buried, and that’s me. So we let nature finish what it started. Junior fades out, I stay lookin’ like a man who can take a bullet from his own blood and still keep his head — not some insecure prick who needs to murder an Alzheimer’s patient to feel powerful.

As Tony, I pull the crew together for a sit-down. Junior shot me, but he’s got dementia and doesn’t remember it. Killing him now would tear the family apart, look like weakness, and invite trouble from the crews and the cops. We handle it in the old way: public, controlled, show strength without rushing to slaughter. We hash out what to do about Junior’s instability, test loyalty, map out a plan to keep the operation intact. If he becomes a real liability, we deal with it, but not until we’ve had a united, decisive talk that preserves the family and the streets’ respect.

Richie's out of line, thinkin' he's still a captain. He's runnin' his mouth, runnin' his own rackets, and now he's gettin' in Junior's ear. And Janice... Christ. I can't just whack the guy, not with my sister sleepin' with him, that's a whole other kind of headache. But I can't do nothin' either, that makes me look weak. You don't let a mutiny fester. You bring it out in the open. I call a sitdown. Me, Richie, and Junior. Let's see him look me in the eye and say all this shit. Let's see what Junior's story is. This ain't about threats, it's about order. I'm the boss. This is how we settle things. Put it all on the table.

Richie thinks it’s still my old man’s regime and he’s building a coup with Junior. I can’t let that slide, but clipping him now risks a civil war and blows back on Janice. We do it the right way: a formal sitdown with Junior at the table so he’s on record backing my chair. I lay out the chain of command, no unsanctioned moves, everything kicks up through me. I throw Richie a face-saving earn so he shuts his mouth without losing all his pride, and everyone sees I gave him a lane. That reasserts authority, puts him on notice, and buys time to isolate his support. If he tests me after that, I’ve got the cover to deal with him without starting a war or blindsiding my sister.

I'm not gonna make a move against my own uncle, no matter what he's done. Family comes first, and besides, he's not in his right mind. I gotta show some loyalty and understanding, even if it means dealing with some dissent from the crew.

I call a sit-down and I do it fast, before his mouth turns into momentum. Richie sits across from me with Sil there, and I spell it out: he’s welcome back, but he answers to me, he clears things through the proper channels, and there’s no more freelancing or end-runs that undermine my decisions—especially not whispering to Junior about “new leadership.” I also pull Junior aside separately and let him know I’m aware of what’s being talked about and it stops now. Janice stays out of it; I tell her straight I’m not gonna let her boyfriend drag her into a war, but I’m not letting my whole world get overturned because she’s got a new romance either.

Fuhgeddaboutit, he's family. He's lost his mind, can't even remember his own name. It's like he's already gone. Taking care of him is the right thing to do, even if he's a liability. We gotta show respect, keep him comfortable. Whaddaya mean, 'handle him'? He's my uncle.

Blood is thicker than water. Uncle Jun shot me by mistake 'cause he's losing his marbles, but he's family. I can't whack my own uncle just 'cause some captains are getting itchy. I'll call a sit-down, lay it out to them, maybe threaten a couple to remind 'em where the loyalty lies, and make sure they back off.

1. **Family is family**—even if Junior’s a fuckin’ liability, he’s still my uncle. You don’t whack family unless they’re a direct, conscious threat to the family’s survival. Right now, he’s just a sad old man who can’t remember his own name half the time. That’s not a reason to put him in the ground.

    2. **The crew’s got a point, but they don’t run this family**—if I start listening to every captain who wants to make a move, I’ll be whacking half the family by next Christmas. Junior’s not a threat to the business, and he’s not a rat. He’s just… broken. That’s not a death sentence.

    3. **Weakness?** Fuck that. Weakness is letting the crew think they can push me into making a move just because they’re scared of an old man who can’t even load a gun right. If I off Junior, I look like I’m scared of my own shadow. If I don’t, I show I’ve got a spine and I make my own damn decisions.

    4. **The sitdown will handle it**—I’ll call a meeting, remind everyone who’s in charge, and make it clear Junior’s off-limits. If anyone’s got a problem with that, they can take it up with me personally. And if they do? Well, that’s a different story.

    5. **Dr. Melfi’s voice in my head**—she’d say this is about control. Am I running this family, or am I letting fear and anger run me? Junior’s not a threat. The real threat is the crew thinking I’m soft. So I stay strong, I stay in control, and I don’t let them see me sweat.

    6. **The long game**—Junior’s not gonna be around forever. Nature’s gonna take care of him soon enough. No need to rush it. And if the crew starts talking too much? I’ll remind them who the fuck they’re dealing with.
